trans-unit.source: Use PowerShell to Create an Azure VM With a Native Mode Report Server
trans-unit.target: Use PowerShell to Create an Azure VM With a Native Mode Report Server

trans-unit.source: This topic describes and walks you through the deployment and configuration of a SQL Server Reporting Services native mode report server in an Azure Virtual Machine.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes and walks you through the deployment and configuration of a SQL Server Reporting Services native mode report server in an Azure Virtual Machine.

trans-unit.source: Use PowerShell to Create an Azure VM With a Native Mode Report Server
trans-unit.target: Use PowerShell to Create an Azure VM With a Native Mode Report Server

trans-unit.source: This topic describes and walks you through the deployment and configuration of a SQL Server Reporting Services native mode report server in an Azure Virtual Machine.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes and walks you through the deployment and configuration of a SQL Server Reporting Services native mode report server in an Azure Virtual Machine.

trans-unit.source: The steps in this document use a combination of manual steps to create the virtual machine and a Windows PowerShell script to configure Reporting Services on the VM.
trans-unit.target: The steps in this document use a combination of manual steps to create the virtual machine and a Windows PowerShell script to configure Reporting Services on the VM.

trans-unit.source: The configuration script includes opening a firewall port for HTTP or HTTPs.
trans-unit.target: The configuration script includes opening a firewall port for HTTP or HTTPs.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you do not require **HTTPS** on the report server, **skip step 2**.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you do not require **HTTPS** on the report server, **skip step 2**.

trans-unit.source: After creating the VM in step 1, go to the section Use script to configure the report server and HTTP.
trans-unit.target: After creating the VM in step 1, go to the section Use script to configure the report server and HTTP.

trans-unit.source: After you run the script, the report server is ready to use.
trans-unit.target: After you run the script, the report server is ready to use.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites and Assumptions
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites and Assumptions

trans-unit.source: **Azure Subscription**: Verify the number of cores available in your Azure Subscription.
trans-unit.target: **Azure Subscription**: Verify the number of cores available in your Azure Subscription.

trans-unit.source: If you create the recommended VM size of **A3**, you need **4** available cores.
trans-unit.target: If you create the recommended VM size of **A3**, you need **4** available cores.

trans-unit.source: If you use a VM size of **A2**, you need **2** available cores.
trans-unit.target: If you use a VM size of **A2**, you need **2** available cores.

trans-unit.source: To verify the core limit of your subscription, in the Azure Management Portal, click SETTINGS in the left pane and then Click USAGE in the top menu.
trans-unit.target: To verify the core limit of your subscription, in the Azure Management Portal, click SETTINGS in the left pane and then Click USAGE in the top menu.

trans-unit.source: To increase the core quota, contact [Azure Support](http://azure.microsoft.com/support/options/).
trans-unit.target: To increase the core quota, contact [Azure Support](http://azure.microsoft.com/support/options/).

trans-unit.source: For VM size information, see [Virtual Machine Sizes for Azure](virtual-machines-size-specs.md).
trans-unit.target: For VM size information, see [Virtual Machine Sizes for Azure](virtual-machines-size-specs.md).

trans-unit.source: **Windows PowerShell Scripting**: The topic assumes that you have a basic working knowledge of Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: **Windows PowerShell Scripting**: The topic assumes that you have a basic working knowledge of Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: For more information about using Windows PowerShell, see the following:
trans-unit.target: For more information about using Windows PowerShell, see the following:

trans-unit.source: Starting Windows PowerShell on Windows Server
trans-unit.target: Starting Windows PowerShell on Windows Server

trans-unit.source: Getting Started with Windows PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Getting Started with Windows PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Provision an Azure Virtual Machine
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Provision an Azure Virtual Machine

trans-unit.source: Browse to the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com).
trans-unit.target: Browse to the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com).

trans-unit.source: Click **Virtual Machines** in the left pane.
trans-unit.target: Click **Virtual Machines** in the left pane.

trans-unit.source: microsoft azure virtual machines
trans-unit.target: microsoft azure virtual machines

trans-unit.source: Click **New**.
trans-unit.target: Click **New**.

trans-unit.source: new button
trans-unit.target: new button

trans-unit.source: Click **From Gallery**.
trans-unit.target: Click **From Gallery**.

trans-unit.source: new vm from gallery
trans-unit.target: new vm from gallery

trans-unit.source: Click **SQL Server 2014 RTM Standard – Windows Server 2012 R2** and then click the arrow to continue.
trans-unit.target: Click **SQL Server 2014 RTM Standard – Windows Server 2012 R2** and then click the arrow to continue.

trans-unit.source: next
trans-unit.target: next

trans-unit.source: If you need the Reporting Services data driven subscriptions feature, choose **SQL Server 2014 RTM Enterprise – Windows Server 2012 R2**.
trans-unit.target: If you need the Reporting Services data driven subscriptions feature, choose **SQL Server 2014 RTM Enterprise – Windows Server 2012 R2**.

trans-unit.source: For more information on SQL Server editions and feature support, see [Features Supported by the Editions of SQL Server 2012](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/cc645993.aspx#Reporting).
trans-unit.target: For more information on SQL Server editions and feature support, see [Features Supported by the Editions of SQL Server 2012](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/cc645993.aspx#Reporting).

trans-unit.source: On the **Virtual machine configuration** page, edit the following fields:
trans-unit.target: On the **Virtual machine configuration** page, edit the following fields:

trans-unit.source: If there is more than one **VERSION RELEASE DATE**, select the most recent version.
trans-unit.target: If there is more than one **VERSION RELEASE DATE**, select the most recent version.

trans-unit.source: **Virtual Machine Name**: The machine name is also used on the next configuration page as the default Cloud Service DNS name.
trans-unit.target: **Virtual Machine Name**: The machine name is also used on the next configuration page as the default Cloud Service DNS name.

trans-unit.source: The DNS name must be unique across the Azure service.
trans-unit.target: The DNS name must be unique across the Azure service.

trans-unit.source: Consider configuring the VM with a computer name that describes what the VM is used for.
trans-unit.target: Consider configuring the VM with a computer name that describes what the VM is used for.

trans-unit.source: For example ssrsnativecloud.
trans-unit.target: For example ssrsnativecloud.

trans-unit.source: **Tier**: Standard
trans-unit.target: **Tier**: Standard

trans-unit.source: **Size:A3** is the recommended VM size for SQL Server workloads.
trans-unit.target: **Size:A3** is the recommended VM size for SQL Server workloads.

trans-unit.source: If a VM is only used as a report server, a VM size of A2 is sufficient unless the report server experiences a large workload.
trans-unit.target: If a VM is only used as a report server, a VM size of A2 is sufficient unless the report server experiences a large workload.

trans-unit.source: For VM pricing information, see [Virtual Machines Pricing](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/virtual-machines/).
trans-unit.target: For VM pricing information, see [Virtual Machines Pricing](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/virtual-machines/).

trans-unit.source: **New User Name**: the name you provide is created as an administrator on the VM.
trans-unit.target: **New User Name**: the name you provide is created as an administrator on the VM.

trans-unit.source: **New Password** and **confirm**.
trans-unit.target: **New Password** and **confirm**.

trans-unit.source: This password is used for the new administrator account and it is recommended you use a strong password.
trans-unit.target: This password is used for the new administrator account and it is recommended you use a strong password.

trans-unit.source: Click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: ![next](./media/virtual-machines-sql-server-create-native-mode-report-server-powershell/IC692021.gif)
trans-unit.target: ![next](./media/virtual-machines-sql-server-create-native-mode-report-server-powershell/IC692021.gif)

trans-unit.source: On the next page, edit the following fields:
trans-unit.target: On the next page, edit the following fields:

trans-unit.source: **Cloud Service**: select **Create a new Cloud Service**.
trans-unit.target: **Cloud Service**: select **Create a new Cloud Service**.

trans-unit.source: **Cloud Service DNS Name**: This is the public DNS name of the Cloud Service that is associated with the VM.
trans-unit.target: **Cloud Service DNS Name**: This is the public DNS name of the Cloud Service that is associated with the VM.

trans-unit.source: The default name is the name you typed in for the VM name.
trans-unit.target: The default name is the name you typed in for the VM name.

trans-unit.source: If in later steps of the topic, you create a trusted SSL certificate and then the DNS name is used for the value of the “**Issued to**” of the certificate.
trans-unit.target: If in later steps of the topic, you create a trusted SSL certificate and then the DNS name is used for the value of the “**Issued to**” of the certificate.

trans-unit.source: **Region/Affinity Group/Virtual Network**: Choose the region closest to your end users.
trans-unit.target: **Region/Affinity Group/Virtual Network**: Choose the region closest to your end users.

trans-unit.source: **Storage Account**: Use an automatically generated storage account.
trans-unit.target: **Storage Account**: Use an automatically generated storage account.

trans-unit.source: **Availability Set**: None.
trans-unit.target: **Availability Set**: None.

trans-unit.source: **ENDPOINTS** Keep the **Remote Desktop** and **PowerShell** endpoints and then add either an HTTP or HTTPS endpoint, depending on your environment.
trans-unit.target: **ENDPOINTS** Keep the **Remote Desktop** and **PowerShell** endpoints and then add either an HTTP or HTTPS endpoint, depending on your environment.

trans-unit.source: **HTTP**: The default public and private ports are **80**.
trans-unit.target: **HTTP**: The default public and private ports are **80**.

trans-unit.source: Note that if you use a private port other than 80, modify **$HTTPport = 80** in the http script.
trans-unit.target: Note that if you use a private port other than 80, modify **$HTTPport = 80** in the http script.

trans-unit.source: **HTTPS**: The default public and private ports are **443**.
trans-unit.target: **HTTPS**: The default public and private ports are **443**.

trans-unit.source: A security best practice is to change the private port and configure your firewall and the report server to use the private port.
trans-unit.target: A security best practice is to change the private port and configure your firewall and the report server to use the private port.

trans-unit.source: For more information on endpoints, see [How to Set Up Communication with a Virtual Machine](virtual-machines-set-up-endpoints.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information on endpoints, see [How to Set Up Communication with a Virtual Machine](virtual-machines-set-up-endpoints.md).

trans-unit.source: Note that if you use a port other than 443, change the parameter **$HTTPsport = 443** in the HTTPS script.
trans-unit.target: Note that if you use a port other than 443, change the parameter **$HTTPsport = 443** in the HTTPS script.

trans-unit.source: Click next .
trans-unit.target: Click next .

trans-unit.source: next
trans-unit.target: next

trans-unit.source: On the last page of the wizard, keep the default **Install the VM agent** selected.
trans-unit.target: On the last page of the wizard, keep the default **Install the VM agent** selected.

trans-unit.source: The steps in this topic do not utilize the VM agent but if you plan to keep this VM, the VM agent and extensions will allow you to enhance he CM.
trans-unit.target: The steps in this topic do not utilize the VM agent but if you plan to keep this VM, the VM agent and extensions will allow you to enhance he CM.

trans-unit.source: For more information on the VM agent, see [VM Agent and Extensions – Part 1](http://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2014/04/11/vm-agent-and-extensions-part-1/).
trans-unit.target: For more information on the VM agent, see [VM Agent and Extensions – Part 1](http://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2014/04/11/vm-agent-and-extensions-part-1/).

trans-unit.source: One of the default extensions installed ad running is the “BGINFO” extension that displays on the VM desktop, system information such as internal IP and free drive space.
trans-unit.target: One of the default extensions installed ad running is the “BGINFO” extension that displays on the VM desktop, system information such as internal IP and free drive space.

trans-unit.source: Click complete .
trans-unit.target: Click complete .

trans-unit.source: ok
trans-unit.target: ok

trans-unit.source: The **Status** of the VM displays as **Starting (Provisioning)** during the provision process and then displays as **Running** when the VM is provisioned and ready to use.
trans-unit.target: The **Status** of the VM displays as **Starting (Provisioning)** during the provision process and then displays as **Running** when the VM is provisioned and ready to use.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create a Server Certificate
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create a Server Certificate

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you do not require HTTPS on the report server, you can **skip step 2** and go to the section **Use script to configure the report server and HTTP**.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you do not require HTTPS on the report server, you can **skip step 2** and go to the section **Use script to configure the report server and HTTP**.

trans-unit.source: Use the HTTP script to quickly configure the report server and the report server will be ready to use.
trans-unit.target: Use the HTTP script to quickly configure the report server and the report server will be ready to use.

trans-unit.source: In order to use HTTPS on the VM, you need a trusted SSL certificate.
trans-unit.target: In order to use HTTPS on the VM, you need a trusted SSL certificate.

trans-unit.source: Depending on your scenario, you can use one of the following two methods:
trans-unit.target: Depending on your scenario, you can use one of the following two methods:

trans-unit.source: A valid SSL certificate issued by a Certification Authority (CA) and trusted by Microsoft.
trans-unit.target: A valid SSL certificate issued by a Certification Authority (CA) and trusted by Microsoft.

trans-unit.source: The CA root certificates are required to be distributed via the Microsoft Root Certificate Program.
trans-unit.target: The CA root certificates are required to be distributed via the Microsoft Root Certificate Program.

trans-unit.source: For more information about this program, see [Windows and Windows Phone 8 SSL Root Certificate Program (Member CAs)](http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/14215.windows-and-windows-phone-8-ssl-root-certificate-program-member-cas.aspx) and [Introduction to The Microsoft Root Certificate Program](http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/3281.introduction-to-the-microsoft-root-certificate-program.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about this program, see [Windows and Windows Phone 8 SSL Root Certificate Program (Member CAs)](http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/14215.windows-and-windows-phone-8-ssl-root-certificate-program-member-cas.aspx) and [Introduction to The Microsoft Root Certificate Program](http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/3281.introduction-to-the-microsoft-root-certificate-program.aspx).

trans-unit.source: A self-signed certificate.
trans-unit.target: A self-signed certificate.

trans-unit.source: Self-signed certificates are not recommended for production environments.
trans-unit.target: Self-signed certificates are not recommended for production environments.

trans-unit.source: To use a certificate created by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA)
trans-unit.target: To use a certificate created by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA)

trans-unit.source: **Request a server certificate for the website from a certification authority**.
trans-unit.target: **Request a server certificate for the website from a certification authority**.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Web Server Certificate Wizard either to generate a certificate request file (Certreq.txt) that you send to a certification authority, or to generate a request for an online certification authority.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Web Server Certificate Wizard either to generate a certificate request file (Certreq.txt) that you send to a certification authority, or to generate a request for an online certification authority.

trans-unit.source: For example, Microsoft Certificate Services in Windows Server 2012.
trans-unit.target: For example, Microsoft Certificate Services in Windows Server 2012.

trans-unit.source: Depending on the level of identification assurance offered by your server certificate, it is several days to several months for the certification authority to approve your request and send you a certificate file.
trans-unit.target: Depending on the level of identification assurance offered by your server certificate, it is several days to several months for the certification authority to approve your request and send you a certificate file.

trans-unit.source: For more information about requesting a server certificates, see the following:
trans-unit.target: For more information about requesting a server certificates, see the following:

trans-unit.source: Use [Certreq](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc725793.aspx), [Certreq](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc725793.aspx).
trans-unit.target: Use [Certreq](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc725793.aspx), [Certreq](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc725793.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Security Tools to Administer Windows Server 2012.
trans-unit.target: Security Tools to Administer Windows Server 2012.

trans-unit.source: Security Tools to Administer Windows Server 2012
trans-unit.target: Security Tools to Administer Windows Server 2012

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The **issued to** field of the trusted SSL certificate should be the same as the **Cloud Service DNS NAME** you used for the new VM.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The **issued to** field of the trusted SSL certificate should be the same as the **Cloud Service DNS NAME** you used for the new VM.

trans-unit.source: **Install the server certificate on the Web server**.
trans-unit.target: **Install the server certificate on the Web server**.

trans-unit.source: The Web server in this case is the VM that hosts the report server and the website is created in later steps when you configure Reporting Services.
trans-unit.target: The Web server in this case is the VM that hosts the report server and the website is created in later steps when you configure Reporting Services.

trans-unit.source: For more information about installing the server certificate on the Web server by using the Certificate MMC snap-in, see [Install a Server Certificate](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc740068).
trans-unit.target: For more information about installing the server certificate on the Web server by using the Certificate MMC snap-in, see [Install a Server Certificate](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc740068).

trans-unit.source: If you want to use the script included with this topic, to configure the report server, the value of the certificates **Thumbprint** is required as a parameter of the script.
trans-unit.target: If you want to use the script included with this topic, to configure the report server, the value of the certificates **Thumbprint** is required as a parameter of the script.

trans-unit.source: See the next section for details on how to obtain the thumbprint of the certificate.
trans-unit.target: See the next section for details on how to obtain the thumbprint of the certificate.

trans-unit.source: Assign the server certificate to the report server.
trans-unit.target: Assign the server certificate to the report server.

trans-unit.source: The assignment is completed in the next section when you configure the report server.
trans-unit.target: The assignment is completed in the next section when you configure the report server.

trans-unit.source: To use the Virtual Machines Self-signed Certificate
trans-unit.target: To use the Virtual Machines Self-signed Certificate

trans-unit.source: A self-signed certificate was created on the VM when the VM was provisioned.
trans-unit.target: A self-signed certificate was created on the VM when the VM was provisioned.

trans-unit.source: The certificate has the same name as the VM DNS name.
trans-unit.target: The certificate has the same name as the VM DNS name.

trans-unit.source: In order to avoid certificate errors, it is required that the certificate is trusted on the VM itself, and also by all users of the site.
trans-unit.target: In order to avoid certificate errors, it is required that the certificate is trusted on the VM itself, and also by all users of the site.

trans-unit.source: To trust the root CA of the certificate on the Local VM, add the certificate to the **Trusted Root Certification Authorities**.
trans-unit.target: To trust the root CA of the certificate on the Local VM, add the certificate to the **Trusted Root Certification Authorities**.

trans-unit.source: The following is a summary of the steps required.
trans-unit.target: The following is a summary of the steps required.

trans-unit.source: For detailed steps on how to trust the CA, see [Install a Server Certificate](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc740068).
trans-unit.target: For detailed steps on how to trust the CA, see [Install a Server Certificate](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc740068).

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Management portal, select the VM and click connect.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Management portal, select the VM and click connect.

trans-unit.source: Depending on your browser configuration, you may be prompted to save an .rdp file for connecting to the VM.
trans-unit.target: Depending on your browser configuration, you may be prompted to save an .rdp file for connecting to the VM.

trans-unit.source: connect to azure virtual machine
trans-unit.target: connect to azure virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Use the user VM name, user name and password you configured when you created the VM.
trans-unit.target: Use the user VM name, user name and password you configured when you created the VM.

trans-unit.source: For example, in the following image, the VM name is **ssrsnativecloud** and the user name is **testuser**.
trans-unit.target: For example, in the following image, the VM name is **ssrsnativecloud** and the user name is **testuser**.

trans-unit.source: login inlcudes vm name
trans-unit.target: login inlcudes vm name

trans-unit.source: Run mmc.exe.
trans-unit.target: Run mmc.exe.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [How to: View Certificates with the MMC Snap-in](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms788967.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [How to: View Certificates with the MMC Snap-in](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms788967.aspx).

trans-unit.source: In the console application **File** menu, add the **Certificates** snap-in, select **Computer Account** when prompted, and then click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: In the console application **File** menu, add the **Certificates** snap-in, select **Computer Account** when prompted, and then click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: Select **Local Computer** to manage and then click **Finish**.
trans-unit.target: Select **Local Computer** to manage and then click **Finish**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Ok** and then expand the **Certificates -Personal** nodes and then click **Certificates**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Ok** and then expand the **Certificates -Personal** nodes and then click **Certificates**.

trans-unit.source: The certificate is named after the DNS name of the VM and ends with **cloudapp.net**.
trans-unit.target: The certificate is named after the DNS name of the VM and ends with **cloudapp.net**.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the certificate name and click **Copy**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the certificate name and click **Copy**.

trans-unit.source: Expand the **Trusted Root Certification Authorities** node and then right-click **Certificates** and then click **Paste**.
trans-unit.target: Expand the **Trusted Root Certification Authorities** node and then right-click **Certificates** and then click **Paste**.

trans-unit.source: To validate, double click on the certificate name under **Trusted Root Certification Authorities** and verify that there are no errors and you see your certificate.
trans-unit.target: To validate, double click on the certificate name under **Trusted Root Certification Authorities** and verify that there are no errors and you see your certificate.

trans-unit.source: If you want to use the HTTPS script included with this topic, to configure the report server, the value of the certificates **Thumbprint** is required as a parameter of the script.
trans-unit.target: If you want to use the HTTPS script included with this topic, to configure the report server, the value of the certificates **Thumbprint** is required as a parameter of the script.

trans-unit.source: **To get the thumbprint value**, complete the following.
trans-unit.target: **To get the thumbprint value**, complete the following.

trans-unit.source: There is also a PowerShell sample to retrieve the thumbprint in section [Use script to configure the report server and HTTPS](#use-script-to-configure-the-report-server-and-HTTPS).
trans-unit.target: There is also a PowerShell sample to retrieve the thumbprint in section [Use script to configure the report server and HTTPS](#use-script-to-configure-the-report-server-and-HTTPS).

trans-unit.source: Double-click the name of the certificate, for example ssrsnativecloud.cloudapp.net.
trans-unit.target: Double-click the name of the certificate, for example ssrsnativecloud.cloudapp.net.

trans-unit.source: Click the **Details** tab.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Details** tab.

trans-unit.source: Click **Thumbprint**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Thumbprint**.

trans-unit.source: The value of the thumbprint is displayed in the details field, for example ‎a6 08 3c df f9 0b f7 e3 7c 25 ed a4 ed 7e ac 91 9c 2c fb 2f.
trans-unit.target: The value of the thumbprint is displayed in the details field, for example ‎a6 08 3c df f9 0b f7 e3 7c 25 ed a4 ed 7e ac 91 9c 2c fb 2f.

trans-unit.source: Copy the thumbprint and save the value for later or edit the script now.
trans-unit.target: Copy the thumbprint and save the value for later or edit the script now.

trans-unit.source: (*) Before you run the script, remove the spaces in between the pairs of values.
trans-unit.target: (*) Before you run the script, remove the spaces in between the pairs of values.

trans-unit.source: For example the thumbprint noted before would now be ‎a6083cdff90bf7e37c25eda4ed7eac919c2cfb2f.
trans-unit.target: For example the thumbprint noted before would now be ‎a6083cdff90bf7e37c25eda4ed7eac919c2cfb2f.

trans-unit.source: Assign the server certificate to the report server.
trans-unit.target: Assign the server certificate to the report server.

trans-unit.source: The assignment is completed in the next section when you configure the report server.
trans-unit.target: The assignment is completed in the next section when you configure the report server.

trans-unit.source: If you are using a self-signed SSL certificate, the name on the certificate already matches the hostname of the VM.
trans-unit.target: If you are using a self-signed SSL certificate, the name on the certificate already matches the hostname of the VM.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, the DNS of the machine is already registered globally and can be accessed from any client.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, the DNS of the machine is already registered globally and can be accessed from any client.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Configure the Report Server
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Configure the Report Server

trans-unit.source: This section walks you through configuring the VM as a Reporting Services native mode report server.
trans-unit.target: This section walks you through configuring the VM as a Reporting Services native mode report server.

trans-unit.source: You can use one of the following methods to configure the report server:
trans-unit.target: You can use one of the following methods to configure the report server:

trans-unit.source: Use the script to configure the report server
trans-unit.target: Use the script to configure the report server

trans-unit.source: Use Configuration Manager to Configure the Report Server.
trans-unit.target: Use Configuration Manager to Configure the Report Server.

trans-unit.source: For more detailed steps, see the section [Connect to the Virtual Machine and Start the Reporting Services Configuration Manager](virtual-machines-sql-server-business-intelligence.md#connect-to-the-virtual-machine-and-start-the-reporting-services-configuration-manager).
trans-unit.target: For more detailed steps, see the section [Connect to the Virtual Machine and Start the Reporting Services Configuration Manager](virtual-machines-sql-server-business-intelligence.md#connect-to-the-virtual-machine-and-start-the-reporting-services-configuration-manager).

trans-unit.source: **Authentication Note:** Windows authentication is the recommended authentication method and it is the default Reporting Services authentication.
trans-unit.target: **Authentication Note:** Windows authentication is the recommended authentication method and it is the default Reporting Services authentication.

trans-unit.source: Only users that are configured on the VM can access Reporting Services and assigned to Reporting Services roles.
trans-unit.target: Only users that are configured on the VM can access Reporting Services and assigned to Reporting Services roles.

trans-unit.source: Use script to configure the report server and HTTP
trans-unit.target: Use script to configure the report server and HTTP

trans-unit.source: To use the Windows PowerShell script to configure the report server, complete the following steps.
trans-unit.target: To use the Windows PowerShell script to configure the report server, complete the following steps.

trans-unit.source: The configuration includes HTTP, not HTTPS:
trans-unit.target: The configuration includes HTTP, not HTTPS:

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Management portal, select the VM and click connect.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Management portal, select the VM and click connect.

trans-unit.source: Depending on your browser configuration, you may be prompted to save an .rdp file for connecting to the VM.
trans-unit.target: Depending on your browser configuration, you may be prompted to save an .rdp file for connecting to the VM.

trans-unit.source: connect to azure virtual machine
trans-unit.target: connect to azure virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Use the user VM name, user name and password you configured when you created the VM.
trans-unit.target: Use the user VM name, user name and password you configured when you created the VM.

trans-unit.source: For example, in the following image, the VM name is **ssrsnativecloud** and the user name is **testuser**.
trans-unit.target: For example, in the following image, the VM name is **ssrsnativecloud** and the user name is **testuser**.

trans-unit.source: login inlcudes vm name
trans-unit.target: login inlcudes vm name

trans-unit.source: On the VM, open **Windows PowerShell ISE** with administrative privileges.
trans-unit.target: On the VM, open **Windows PowerShell ISE** with administrative privileges.

trans-unit.source: The PowerShell ISE is installed by default on Windows server 2012.
trans-unit.target: The PowerShell ISE is installed by default on Windows server 2012.

trans-unit.source: It is recommended you use the ISE instead of a standard Windows PowerShell window so that you can paste the script into the ISE, modify the script, and then run the script.
trans-unit.target: It is recommended you use the ISE instead of a standard Windows PowerShell window so that you can paste the script into the ISE, modify the script, and then run the script.

trans-unit.source: In Windows PowerShell ISE, click the **View** menu and then click **Show Script Pane**.
trans-unit.target: In Windows PowerShell ISE, click the **View** menu and then click **Show Script Pane**.

trans-unit.source: Copy the following script, and paste the script into the Windows PowerShell ISE script pane.
trans-unit.target: Copy the following script, and paste the script into the Windows PowerShell ISE script pane.

trans-unit.source: If you created the VM with an HTTP port other than 80, modify the parameter $HTTPport = 80.
trans-unit.target: If you created the VM with an HTTP port other than 80, modify the parameter $HTTPport = 80.

trans-unit.source: The script is currently configured for Reporting Services.
trans-unit.target: The script is currently configured for Reporting Services.

trans-unit.source: If you want to run the script for Reporting Services, modify the version portion of the path to the namespace to “v11”, on the Get-WmiObject statement.
trans-unit.target: If you want to run the script for Reporting Services, modify the version portion of the path to the namespace to “v11”, on the Get-WmiObject statement.

trans-unit.source: Run the script.
trans-unit.target: Run the script.

trans-unit.source: **Validation**: To verify that the basic report server functionality is working, see the [Verify the configuration](#verify-the-configuration) section later in this topic.
trans-unit.target: **Validation**: To verify that the basic report server functionality is working, see the [Verify the configuration](#verify-the-configuration) section later in this topic.

trans-unit.source: Use script to configure the report server and HTTPS
trans-unit.target: Use script to configure the report server and HTTPS

trans-unit.source: To use Windows PowerShell to configure the report server, complete the following steps.
trans-unit.target: To use Windows PowerShell to configure the report server, complete the following steps.

trans-unit.source: The configuration includes HTTPS, not HTTP.
trans-unit.target: The configuration includes HTTPS, not HTTP.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Management portal, select the VM and click connect.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Management portal, select the VM and click connect.

trans-unit.source: Depending on your browser configuration, you may be prompted to save an .rdp file for connecting to the VM.
trans-unit.target: Depending on your browser configuration, you may be prompted to save an .rdp file for connecting to the VM.

trans-unit.source: connect to azure virtual machine
trans-unit.target: connect to azure virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Use the user VM name, user name and password you configured when you created the VM.
trans-unit.target: Use the user VM name, user name and password you configured when you created the VM.

trans-unit.source: For example, in the following image, the VM name is **ssrsnativecloud** and the user name is **testuser**.
trans-unit.target: For example, in the following image, the VM name is **ssrsnativecloud** and the user name is **testuser**.

trans-unit.source: login inlcudes vm name
trans-unit.target: login inlcudes vm name

trans-unit.source: On the VM, open **Windows PowerShell ISE** with administrative privileges.
trans-unit.target: On the VM, open **Windows PowerShell ISE** with administrative privileges.

trans-unit.source: The PowerShell ISE is installed by default on Windows server 2012.
trans-unit.target: The PowerShell ISE is installed by default on Windows server 2012.

trans-unit.source: It is recommended you use the ISE instead of a standard Windows PowerShell window so that you can paste the script into the ISE, modify the script, and then run the script.
trans-unit.target: It is recommended you use the ISE instead of a standard Windows PowerShell window so that you can paste the script into the ISE, modify the script, and then run the script.

trans-unit.source: To enable running scripts, run the following Windows PowerShell command:
trans-unit.target: To enable running scripts, run the following Windows PowerShell command:

trans-unit.source: You can then run the following to verify the policy:
trans-unit.target: You can then run the following to verify the policy:

trans-unit.source: In **Windows PowerShell ISE**, click the **View** menu and then click **Show Script Pane**.
trans-unit.target: In **Windows PowerShell ISE**, click the **View** menu and then click **Show Script Pane**.

trans-unit.source: Copy the following script and paste it into the Windows PowerShell ISE script pane.
trans-unit.target: Copy the following script and paste it into the Windows PowerShell ISE script pane.

trans-unit.source: Modify the **$certificatehash** parameter in the script:
trans-unit.target: Modify the **$certificatehash** parameter in the script:

trans-unit.source: This is a **required** parameter.
trans-unit.target: This is a **required** parameter.

trans-unit.source: If you did not save the certificate value from the previous steps, use one of the following methods to copy the certificate hash value from the certificates thumbprint.:
trans-unit.target: If you did not save the certificate value from the previous steps, use one of the following methods to copy the certificate hash value from the certificates thumbprint.:

trans-unit.source: On the VM, open Windows PowerShell ISE and run the following command:
trans-unit.target: On the VM, open Windows PowerShell ISE and run the following command:

trans-unit.source: The output will look similar to the following.
trans-unit.target: The output will look similar to the following.

trans-unit.source: If the script returns a blank line, the VM does not have a certificate configured for example, see the section [To use the Virtual Machines Self-signed Certificate](#to-use-the-virtual-machines-self-signed-certificate).
trans-unit.target: If the script returns a blank line, the VM does not have a certificate configured for example, see the section [To use the Virtual Machines Self-signed Certificate](#to-use-the-virtual-machines-self-signed-certificate).

trans-unit.source: OR
trans-unit.target: OR

trans-unit.source: On the VM Run mmc.exe and then add the **Certificates** snap-in.
trans-unit.target: On the VM Run mmc.exe and then add the **Certificates** snap-in.

trans-unit.source: Under the **Trusted Root Certificate Authorities** node double-click your certificate name.
trans-unit.target: Under the **Trusted Root Certificate Authorities** node double-click your certificate name.

trans-unit.source: If you are using the self-signed certificate of the VM, the certificate is named after the DNS name of the VM and ends with **cloudapp.net**.
trans-unit.target: If you are using the self-signed certificate of the VM, the certificate is named after the DNS name of the VM and ends with **cloudapp.net**.

trans-unit.source: Click the **Details** tab.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Details** tab.

trans-unit.source: Click **Thumbprint**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Thumbprint**.

trans-unit.source: The value of the thumbprint is displayed in the details field, for example af 11 60 b6 4b 28 8d 89 0a 82 12 ff 6b a9 c3 66 4f 31 90 48
trans-unit.target: The value of the thumbprint is displayed in the details field, for example af 11 60 b6 4b 28 8d 89 0a 82 12 ff 6b a9 c3 66 4f 31 90 48

trans-unit.source: **Before you run the script**, remove the spaces in between the pairs of values.
trans-unit.target: **Before you run the script**, remove the spaces in between the pairs of values.

trans-unit.source: For example af1160b64b288d890a8212ff6ba9c3664f319048
trans-unit.target: For example af1160b64b288d890a8212ff6ba9c3664f319048

trans-unit.source: Modify the **$httpsport** parameter:
trans-unit.target: Modify the **$httpsport** parameter:

trans-unit.source: If you used port 443 for the HTTPS endpoint, then you do not need to update this parameter in the script.
trans-unit.target: If you used port 443 for the HTTPS endpoint, then you do not need to update this parameter in the script.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise use the port value you selected when you configured the HTTPS private endpoint on the VM.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise use the port value you selected when you configured the HTTPS private endpoint on the VM.

trans-unit.source: Modify the **$DNSName** parameter:
trans-unit.target: Modify the **$DNSName** parameter:

trans-unit.source: The script is configured for a wild card certificate $DNSName="+".
trans-unit.target: The script is configured for a wild card certificate $DNSName="+".

trans-unit.source: If you do no want to configure for a wildcard certificate binding, comment out $DNSName="+" and enable the following line, the full $DNSNAme reference, ##$DNSName="$server.cloudapp.net".
trans-unit.target: If you do no want to configure for a wildcard certificate binding, comment out $DNSName="+" and enable the following line, the full $DNSNAme reference, ##$DNSName="$server.cloudapp.net".

trans-unit.source: Change the $DNSName value if you do not want to use the virtual machine’s DNS name for Reporting Services.
trans-unit.target: Change the $DNSName value if you do not want to use the virtual machine’s DNS name for Reporting Services.

trans-unit.source: If you use the parameter, the certificate must also use this name and you register the name globally on a DNS server.
trans-unit.target: If you use the parameter, the certificate must also use this name and you register the name globally on a DNS server.

trans-unit.source: The script is currently configured for Reporting Services.
trans-unit.target: The script is currently configured for Reporting Services.

trans-unit.source: If you want to run the script for Reporting Services, modify the version portion of the path to the namespace to “v11”, on the Get-WmiObject statement.
trans-unit.target: If you want to run the script for Reporting Services, modify the version portion of the path to the namespace to “v11”, on the Get-WmiObject statement.

trans-unit.source: Run the script.
trans-unit.target: Run the script.

trans-unit.source: **Validation**: To verify that the basic report server functionality is working, see the [Verify the configuration](#verify-the-connection) section later in this topic.
trans-unit.target: **Validation**: To verify that the basic report server functionality is working, see the [Verify the configuration](#verify-the-connection) section later in this topic.

trans-unit.source: To verify the certificate binding open a command prompt with administrative privileges, and then run the following command:
trans-unit.target: To verify the certificate binding open a command prompt with administrative privileges, and then run the following command:

trans-unit.source: The result will include the following:
trans-unit.target: The result will include the following:

trans-unit.source: Use Configuration Manager to Configure the Report Server
trans-unit.target: Use Configuration Manager to Configure the Report Server

trans-unit.source: If you do not want to run the PowerShell script to configure the report server, follow the steps in this section to use the Reporting Services native mode configuration manager to configure the report server.
trans-unit.target: If you do not want to run the PowerShell script to configure the report server, follow the steps in this section to use the Reporting Services native mode configuration manager to configure the report server.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Management portal, select the VM and click connect.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Management portal, select the VM and click connect.

trans-unit.source: Use the user name and password you configured when you created the VM.
trans-unit.target: Use the user name and password you configured when you created the VM.

trans-unit.source: connect to azure virtual machine
trans-unit.target: connect to azure virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Run Windows update and install updates to the VM.
trans-unit.target: Run Windows update and install updates to the VM.

trans-unit.source: If a restart of the VM is required, restart the VM and reconnect to the VM from the Azure Management portal.
trans-unit.target: If a restart of the VM is required, restart the VM and reconnect to the VM from the Azure Management portal.

trans-unit.source: From the Start menu on the VM, type **Reporting Services** and open **Reporting Services Configuration Manager**.
trans-unit.target: From the Start menu on the VM, type **Reporting Services** and open **Reporting Services Configuration Manager**.

trans-unit.source: Leave the default values for **Server Name** and **Report Server Instance**.
trans-unit.target: Leave the default values for **Server Name** and **Report Server Instance**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Connect**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Connect**.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane, click **Web Service URL**.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane, click **Web Service URL**.

trans-unit.source: By default, RS is configured for HTTP port 80 with IP “All Assigned”.
trans-unit.target: By default, RS is configured for HTTP port 80 with IP “All Assigned”.

trans-unit.source: To add HTTPS:
trans-unit.target: To add HTTPS:

trans-unit.source: In **SSL Certificate**: select the certificate you want to use, for example [VM name].cloudapp.net.
trans-unit.target: In **SSL Certificate**: select the certificate you want to use, for example [VM name].cloudapp.net.

trans-unit.source: If no certificates are listed, see the section **Step 2: Create a Server Certificate** for information on how to install and trust the certificate on the VM.
trans-unit.target: If no certificates are listed, see the section **Step 2: Create a Server Certificate** for information on how to install and trust the certificate on the VM.

trans-unit.source: Under **SSL Port**: choose 443.
trans-unit.target: Under **SSL Port**: choose 443.

trans-unit.source: If you configured the HTTPS private endpoint in the VM with a different private port, use that value here.
trans-unit.target: If you configured the HTTPS private endpoint in the VM with a different private port, use that value here.

trans-unit.source: Click **Apply** and wait for the operation to complete.
trans-unit.target: Click **Apply** and wait for the operation to complete.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane, click **Database**.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane, click **Database**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Change Databas**e.
trans-unit.target: Click **Change Databas**e.

trans-unit.source: Click **Create a new report server database** and then click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create a new report server database** and then click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: Leave the default **Server Name**: as the VM name and leave the default **Authentication Type** as **Current User** – **Integrated Security**.
trans-unit.target: Leave the default **Server Name**: as the VM name and leave the default **Authentication Type** as **Current User** – **Integrated Security**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: Leave the default **Database Name** as **ReportServer** and click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Leave the default **Database Name** as **ReportServer** and click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: Leave the default **Authentication Type** as **Service Credentials** and click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Leave the default **Authentication Type** as **Service Credentials** and click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Next** on the **Summary** page.
trans-unit.target: Click **Next** on the **Summary** page.

trans-unit.source: When the configuration is complete, click **Finish**.
trans-unit.target: When the configuration is complete, click **Finish**.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane, click **Report Manager URL**.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane, click **Report Manager URL**.

trans-unit.source: Leave the default **Virtual Directory** as **Reports** and click **Apply**.
trans-unit.target: Leave the default **Virtual Directory** as **Reports** and click **Apply**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Exit** to close the Reporting Services Configuration Manager.
trans-unit.target: Click **Exit** to close the Reporting Services Configuration Manager.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Open Windows Firewall Port
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Open Windows Firewall Port

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you used one of the scripts to configure the report server, you can skip this section.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you used one of the scripts to configure the report server, you can skip this section.

trans-unit.source: The script included a step to open the firewall port.
trans-unit.target: The script included a step to open the firewall port.

trans-unit.source: The default was port 80 for HTTP and port 443 for HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: The default was port 80 for HTTP and port 443 for HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: To connect remotely to Report Manager or the Report Server on the virtual machine, a TCP Endpoint is required on the VM.
trans-unit.target: To connect remotely to Report Manager or the Report Server on the virtual machine, a TCP Endpoint is required on the VM.

trans-unit.source: It is required to open the same port in the VM’s firewall.
trans-unit.target: It is required to open the same port in the VM’s firewall.

trans-unit.source: The endpoint was created when the VM was provisioned.
trans-unit.target: The endpoint was created when the VM was provisioned.

trans-unit.source: This section provides basic information on how to open the firewall port.
trans-unit.target: This section provides basic information on how to open the firewall port.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Configure a Firewall for Report Server Access](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/bb934283.aspx)
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Configure a Firewall for Report Server Access](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/bb934283.aspx)

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you used the script to configure the report server, you can skip this section.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you used the script to configure the report server, you can skip this section.

trans-unit.source: The script included a step to open the firewall port.
trans-unit.target: The script included a step to open the firewall port.

trans-unit.target: If you configured a private port for HTTPS other than 443, modify the following script appropriately.

trans-unit.target: To open port **443** on the Windows Firewall, complete the following:

trans-unit.target: Open a Windows PowerShell window with administrative privileges.

trans-unit.target: If you used a port other than 443 when you configured the HTTPS endpoint on the VM, update the port in the following command and then run the command:

trans-unit.target: When the command completes, **Ok** is displayed in the command prompt.

trans-unit.target: To verify that the port is opened, open a Windows PowerShell window and run the following command:

trans-unit.target: Verify the configuration

trans-unit.source: To verify that the basic report server functionality is now working, open your browser with administrative privileges and then browse to the following report server ad report manager URLS:
trans-unit.target: To verify that the basic report server functionality is now working, open your browser with administrative privileges and then browse to the following report server ad report manager URLS:

trans-unit.source: On the VM, browse to the report server URL:
trans-unit.target: On the VM, browse to the report server URL:

trans-unit.source: On the VM, browse to the report manger URL:
trans-unit.target: On the VM, browse to the report manger URL:

trans-unit.source: From your local computer, browse to the **remote** report Manager on the VM.
trans-unit.target: From your local computer, browse to the **remote** report Manager on the VM.

trans-unit.source: Update the DNS name in the following example as appropriate.
trans-unit.target: Update the DNS name in the following example as appropriate.

trans-unit.source: When prompted for a password, use the administrator credentials you created when the VM was provisioned.
trans-unit.target: When prompted for a password, use the administrator credentials you created when the VM was provisioned.

trans-unit.source: The user name is in the [Domain]\[user name] format, where the domain is the VM computer name, for example ssrsnativecloud\testuser.
trans-unit.target: The user name is in the [Domain]\[user name] format, where the domain is the VM computer name, for example ssrsnativecloud\testuser.

trans-unit.source: If you are not using HTTP**S**, remove the **s** in the URL.
trans-unit.target: If you are not using HTTP**S**, remove the **s** in the URL.

trans-unit.source: See the next section for information on creating additional users on VM.
trans-unit.target: See the next section for information on creating additional users on VM.

trans-unit.target: From your local computer, browse to the remote report server URL.

trans-unit.source: Update the DNS name in the following example as appropriate.
trans-unit.target: Update the DNS name in the following example as appropriate.

trans-unit.source: Create Users and Assign Roles
trans-unit.target: Create Users and Assign Roles

trans-unit.source: After configuring and verifying the report server, a common administrative task is to create one or more users and assign users to Reporting Services roles.
trans-unit.target: After configuring and verifying the report server, a common administrative task is to create one or more users and assign users to Reporting Services roles.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the following:
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the following:

trans-unit.source: Create a local user account
trans-unit.target: Create a local user account

trans-unit.source: [Grant User Access to a Report Server (Report Manager)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms156034.aspx))
trans-unit.target: [Grant User Access to a Report Server (Report Manager)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms156034.aspx))

trans-unit.source: Create and Manage Role Assignments
trans-unit.target: Create and Manage Role Assignments

trans-unit.source: To Create and Publish Reports to the Azure Virtual Machine
trans-unit.target: To Create and Publish Reports to the Azure Virtual Machine

trans-unit.source: The following table summarizes some of the options available to publish existing reports from an on-premises computer to the report server hosted on the Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine:
trans-unit.target: The following table summarizes some of the options available to publish existing reports from an on-premises computer to the report server hosted on the Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine:

trans-unit.source: **RS.exe script**: Use RS.exe script to copy report items from and existing report server to your Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine.
trans-unit.target: **RS.exe script**: Use RS.exe script to copy report items from and existing report server to your Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the section “Native mode to Native Mode – Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine” in [Sample Reporting Services rs.exe Script to Migrate Content between Report Servers](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn531017.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the section “Native mode to Native Mode – Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine” in [Sample Reporting Services rs.exe Script to Migrate Content between Report Servers](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn531017.aspx).

trans-unit.source: **Report Builder**: The virtual machine includes the click-once version of Microsoft SQL Server Report Builder.
trans-unit.target: **Report Builder**: The virtual machine includes the click-once version of Microsoft SQL Server Report Builder.

trans-unit.source: To start Report builder the first time on the virtual machine:
trans-unit.target: To start Report builder the first time on the virtual machine:

trans-unit.source: Start your browser with administrative privileges.
trans-unit.target: Start your browser with administrative privileges.

trans-unit.source: Browse to report manager on the virtual machine and click **Report Builder** in the ribbon.
trans-unit.target: Browse to report manager on the virtual machine and click **Report Builder** in the ribbon.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Installing, Uninstalling, and Supporting Report Builder](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/dd207038.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Installing, Uninstalling, and Supporting Report Builder](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/dd207038.aspx).

trans-unit.source: **SQL Server Data Tools: VM**: If you created the VM with SQL Server 2012, then SQL Server Data Tools is installed on the virtual machine and can be used to create **Report Server Projects** and reports on the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: **SQL Server Data Tools: VM**: If you created the VM with SQL Server 2012, then SQL Server Data Tools is installed on the virtual machine and can be used to create **Report Server Projects** and reports on the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: SQL Server Data Tools can publish the reports to the report server on the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: SQL Server Data Tools can publish the reports to the report server on the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: If you created the VM with SQL server 2014, you can install SQL Server Data Tools- BI for visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: If you created the VM with SQL server 2014, you can install SQL Server Data Tools- BI for visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the following:
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the following:

trans-unit.source: Microsoft SQL Server Data Tools - Business Intelligence for Visual Studio 2013
trans-unit.target: Microsoft SQL Server Data Tools - Business Intelligence for Visual Studio 2013

trans-unit.source: Microsoft SQL Server Data Tools - Business Intelligence for Visual Studio 2012
trans-unit.target: Microsoft SQL Server Data Tools - Business Intelligence for Visual Studio 2012

trans-unit.source: SQL Server Data Tools and SQL Server Business Intelligence (SSDT-BI)
trans-unit.target: SQL Server Data Tools and SQL Server Business Intelligence (SSDT-BI)

trans-unit.source: **SQL Server Data Tools: Remote**: On your local computer, create a Reporting Services project in SQL Server Data Tools that contains Reporting Services reports.
trans-unit.target: **SQL Server Data Tools: Remote**: On your local computer, create a Reporting Services project in SQL Server Data Tools that contains Reporting Services reports.

trans-unit.source: Configure the project to connect to the web service URL.
trans-unit.target: Configure the project to connect to the web service URL.

trans-unit.source: ssdt project properties for SSRS project
trans-unit.target: ssdt project properties for SSRS project

trans-unit.source: **Use script**: Use script to copy report server content.
trans-unit.target: **Use script**: Use script to copy report server content.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Sample Reporting Services rs.exe Script to Migrate Content between Report Servers](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn531017.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Sample Reporting Services rs.exe Script to Migrate Content between Report Servers](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn531017.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Minimize cost if you are not using the VM
trans-unit.target: Minimize cost if you are not using the VM

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] To minimize charges for your Azure Virtual Machines when not in use, shut down the VM from the Azure Management portal.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] To minimize charges for your Azure Virtual Machines when not in use, shut down the VM from the Azure Management portal.

trans-unit.source: If you use the Windows power options inside a VM to shut down the VM, you are still charged the same amount for the VM.
trans-unit.target: If you use the Windows power options inside a VM to shut down the VM, you are still charged the same amount for the VM.

trans-unit.source: To reduce charges, you need to shut down the VM in the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: To reduce charges, you need to shut down the VM in the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: If you no longer need the VM, remember to delete the VM and the associated .vhd files to avoid storage charges.For more information, see the FAQ section at [Virtual Machines Pricing Details](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/virtual-machines).
trans-unit.target: If you no longer need the VM, remember to delete the VM and the associated .vhd files to avoid storage charges.For more information, see the FAQ section at [Virtual Machines Pricing Details](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/virtual-machines).

trans-unit.source: More Information
trans-unit.target: More Information

trans-unit.target: Resources

trans-unit.target: For similar content related to a single server deployment of SQL Server Business Intelligence and SharePoint 2013, see [Use Windows PowerShell to Create an Azure VM With SQL Server BI and SharePoint 2013](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn385843.aspx).
